Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 02:25AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi there Binney I don't have any special monitoring with pyc - although my GP knows I take it and approves. The OTC version is identical to the prescription version and the recommended dose is 300 mg (1 x 150 mg twice a day).  It is a standardised product here and is sold as a medecine and not a food or herbal supplement.  It is produced by Winthrop Industries. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: pycnogenol glolite Bahons2

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 07:59AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi there I live in France - Endotelin (contains the same active ingredient as Pycnogenol, but extracted from grape seeds) is available here either 'over-the-counter' (it's very cheap) or on prescription and is sold as a treatment for lymphoedema, as it is thought to support the circulatory system, including the lymphatics.  I've been taking the recommended dose for six months now with no problems at all.  As to whether there is any benefit, I am not sure, as I believe it takes about 6 months for the improvement, if any, to start to show.
Posts.Title: pycnogenol glolite Bahons2

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 04:25AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi bhbull and others Was your onc thinking of Sorafenib (Nexavar)?  It's a new drug for kidney cancer.  Apparently it recently dramatically reduced the leg lymphoedema of a patient with advanced kidney cancer.  The patient was being treated in Australia and this, from the the little I can find that is freely available over the internet, was a totally unexpected side effect. I do 'google' it from time to time, but at the moment there is a charge for the abstract and I haven't taken it any further.  Obviously Sorafenib is a very powerful drug indeed (with some nasty side effects), and I can't see it being prescribed -  yet -  for lymphoedema in its current form.  I am waiting to see if anything new about it pops up in the public domain. While this appears to be very encouraging, it saddens me somewhat any advance in lymphoedema treatment or knowledge very often seems to be stumbled across by someone looking for a cure for something else! Be very interested know if this was what your onc had in mind? Best wishes, all.
Posts.Title: drug trial to reduce lymphedema? bhull Bahons2

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 12:44AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi Carilene I live in France, have lymphoedema in both arms and have met a French surgeon who has done many of these in recent years..  I didn't taken it further because of more health problems. It's my understanding that the procedure remains a little controversial, even in France.  There is no doubt that good results have been obtained, but I also understand that patients were carefully pre-selected for suitability.  I think it is still too early for any long term follow up data to be available. That said, it is a promising development.  Transplants are also being carried out in Germany. I do have some (only a little) general, background information about the French and German lymph node transplants.  If you, or anyone else is interested, do feel free to pm me and I will e-mail it.  Very interested to hear how you get on!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 10:53PM Bahons2 wrote: Hi Teresa I had a right mastectomy (no rads) in 1993, reconstruction 1996.  A few months later I developed lymphoedema.  I think it may have been the last straw for the lymphatics on that side, but how do you prove it?  (To be fair, the lymphoedema is pretty mild) So.....end result, plastic surgeon delighted with his handiwork, me despondent over arm. If I'd been given any indication that reconstruction increases the risk of lymphoedema (and I think that some studies have shown that it does?  Anyone know for sure?) - and I'd never even heard the word until I got it! - I don't think I'd have gone ahead. Just my thoughts.... All the best S.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 04:01PM Bahons2 wrote: Hi all - I'afraid I don't do much for the lymphoedema (Brit spelling!) cause in this respect.  I've gone for concealment/camouflage as much as possible with coloured sleeves/long sleeves/three-quarter sleeves and occasionally no sleeves at all.  I HATE being questioned by people, whether I know them or not, about my physical appearance.  I think it's downright rude.  I'm happy to talk about lymphoedema to people, but on my terms, not because I've been cornered and asked about how weird I look. I find even the most 'attractive' sleeves extremely unsightly and I'm more than happy not to see my own for most of the day!

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 02:49AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi all When I got lymphoedema in both arms a few years ago, my GP wrote to a local cardiovascular consultant asking for his advice on taking BP on legs. I asked her for a copy of his reply as I thought it was very useful to carry with me for hospital visits/stays. Here's what he wrote: 'It should be possible to monitor her blood pressure measured at the ankle. This can be checked by putting a cuff around her thigh and listening in the popliteal fossa (for non-automatic devices). Generally blood pressures measured distally are around 10 mmHg systolic higher than centrally measured BP. This is because the pressure wave form changes on passing into smaller arteries, in much the same way as waves become higher and steeper when they pass into shallow water'. So that's how they can do it - in their own language! However, I too find thigh cuffs uncomfortable and it's perfectly possible, with an automatic device, for them to put an arm cuff around the lower calf and take a reading from there. X S X S

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2009 07:01AM Bahons2 wrote: I'd just like to add that I now live in France and my French oncologist had never heard of Dr Becker, even though I had, years earlier - when I lived in the UK.  I doubt that he's the only one. And just a thought.....perhaps, then, one of the reasons,  that there are no large scale studies of her work could be in part due it being relatively unknown by her compatriates.  Perhaps she lacks patients? As most of us know, most doctors have no scant knowledge of, or much interest in, lymphoedema.  Regarding it as a trivial complaint, they are unlikely to seek out more modern treatments or to inform themselves about it. X S

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 06:13AM - edited Jun 19, 2009 06:15AM by Bahons2 Thanks for the interesting reply, Binney. Whether Avastin ultimately proves to be a weapon in the fight against lymphoedema or just another red herring, I think it will be an absolute tragedy if this study doesn't get off the ground simply for lack of  volunteers. This is because all the wrong messages will be sent out to the wider world.  Such as: An assumption that if they cannot get enough volunteers, there obviously aren't that many people suffering with it in the first place.  WRONG. Another might be that if they cannot get enough volunteers, it doesn't bother sufferers enough for them to want to assist in finding effective treatments/a cure.  WRONG (I hope). World-wide, there isn't nearly enough research into lymphoedema; if this scheme doesn't take place, there will be even less.  I do sympathise with the fear of side effects.  High pressure, for example, is a well known consequence of receiving Avastin, but can be managed with tablets and I understand that it often falls when a course of Avastin is completed. I loathe lymphoedema with every fibre of my being and if it wasn't a geographical impossibility for me to take part, I'd have volunteered.   I ain't gonna die wondering!
Posts.Title: Lymphoedema and Avastin Bahons2 Bahons2

Posts.Title: Lymphoedema and Avastin Bahons2 Bahons2

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2009 11:47AM Bahons2 wrote: I'm of the opinion (and it is just an opinion; I have no facts to back this up) that there are 3 groups of breast cancer patients. Those that will never develop lymphoedema no matter what they do. Those that will develop it no matter what. Those for whom all the preventative measure and precautions will work. If we knew what category we were in.....what Kira says about some people's lymphatic systems being more sluggish than others makes sense to me.  It would be useful if we knew how vigorous our own systems were. I've got bilateral lymphoedema from bc treatment and second time around I bust a gut to avoid getting lymphoedema, all to no avail, which I found heartbreaking.  Altho' because my awareness was very high, I made sure I was treated early, which I think has helped a great deal. X S
Posts.Title: General risk question sejnboys sejnboys

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 09:16AM Bahons2 wrote: Hi All - just like to add a bit a here. While I was still living in England (I live in France now)  in 2006 I went to see Dr Corinne Becker in Paris to see if I was suitable for a lymph node transplant.  She is a lovely lady.  She said I was, and I was intending to have it done when I had the money, as at that time I was not registered in the French system.  Unfortunately, I have had had ongoing problems with my axilla and the surgery is out of the question for the foreseeable future.  which is a real shame, as I am now a French resident and covered by a combination of state funding + private health insurance for it! I am a member of the French Lymphoedema Patients support organisation (AVML) and their latest newsletter mentioned Dr Becker.  From this I gathered that the results ARE good, with very few patients registering no improvement at all, but those selected may not be totally representative, as the lymphoedemas, were, I believe, not the biggest and relatively recent. I think the signs are excellent tho', that this technique will be refined and improved in the years to come and I hope that one day I'll be able to take advantage of it.  In a way, I wouldn't want to be one of the 'early' ones - I'd like someone who'd had loads of practice to do mine! S

X S

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 03:31AM - edited Jul 15, 2009 03:32AM by Bahons2 Hi I've had MRI IV in my foot with no problems.  I think needles in feet are always a bit more painful than in hands or arms, but if yours are really sensitive they could always apply some local anaesthetic first . As for blood draws in feet, using a child/baby cannula instead of an adult can help a lot, too. Hope all goes well! X S
